meta_data.title: The Jews Win Back Their Kingdom, But Can They Keep It?
meta_data.subtitle: Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: Hey everybody, I'm Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast and every time I watch a movie or a TV show that is big sweeping and historical epic or a fantasy historical epic. We get to the end of it and I always want the thing where they show me what happened next. I mean at least give me the white words on the screen where you say then this happened and this happened and show me the pictures and memoriam of everybody. Tell me how they died. When we started doing that yesterday, we started doing the epilogue to the moment in history we've been looking at and we got all the way up through a hundred, ten, hundred and fifteen years after the time of Nehemiah and Ezra that we just spent a bunch of time looking at and we encountered a guy named Alexander the Great, a Macedonian, he's Greek ish and he has defeated a distant descendant of kings, Xerxes and King Artaxerxes, a guy named Darius III and with that Alexander the Great puts the signet ring of the king of Persia on his finger and becomes effectively the final king of the Persian Empire. I think what he did there was already enough to earn Alexander the title the Great but it wasn't enough for Alexander and it's only new, it was conquest. I mean it's like a shark. They sit still and they can't breathe. They're going to have the movement to get the oxygen running over the gills and so Alexander well he's got a lot more conquest ahead of him. Well Alexander pushes his luck as far as he can. He conquers as far as India but ultimately he comes back to Babylon as his troops grow weary of war and he dies there as a young man I believe he was 33 years old. He does not have an heir. He does not name an heir and so as a result four of his generals sometimes collectively referred to as the Diadoki divide up Alexander's newly formed empire and also newly Greekified empire because he intermarried everybody with Greeks and he spread Greek language and two of those generals and their families are going to play a big role moving forward in the story the salucids and the tolemids the Ptolemy family sets up shop in North Egypt in that newly founded Alexandria area and they are very friendly toward the Jewish people in the early going and the Ptolemids initially have custody of Jerusalem as well but then eventually the salucids gain custody of Jerusalem and they are not as nice to the Jews. In fact they are openly antagonistic to the Jews. The salucid emperor still share Alexander's vision for Greekifying the whole world and even though Alexander did not try to inflict that on the Jews when he rolled into Jerusalem he kind of read the room maybe a little better than his generals and their descendants later. The salucids felt like the Jews are not Greekifying well enough we need to make that happen and so they profaned the Jewish temple particularly one leader named Antiochus Epiphanes. He profaned the temple that Zerubbabel had built and he had a lot of luck converting the minds of a lot of young Jewish people to thinking in Greek cultural ways and having Greek cultural values but what's one of the big lessons coming out of Nehemiah if you do that if you adopt all of those foreign ways and you are an ancient Jew bad things are coming well it looks like there was a whole bunch of people in Jerusalem who were still buying Nehemiah's message and they were thinking we cannot go and adopt these Greek ways it doesn't matter how much influence they exert on us we have to be a people set apart we got to honor the Sabbath we got to do all the stuff that our ancestors covenanted that they would do and that we their descendants would do in 444 BC one particular family that stands out is the Maccabees family and interestingly it is an old high priest who in the 160s actually BC he leads of the charge in saying no we have to honor the reforms of the age of Nehemiah and Ezra that we looked at so carefully in the book of Nehemiah we got to honor that and we need to resist these new overlords and his name was Matthias and his descendants would ultimately lead at times a guerrilla war pushing back on the Seleucid Empire in particular Antiochus Epiphanes and they win and they get a kingdom of their own and for almost exactly 100 years the descendants of Matthias and the Maccabees family ruled this Jewish independent kingdom that historians called the Hasmonean dynasty but unfortunately the Hasmonean kings are awful they're corrupt they make all of the same mistakes that the kings of the northern kingdom made in the books of first and second kings they don't honor god they don't get it right it's more of the same stuff that you get throughout the entire Old Testament and ultimately the political intrigue and the mess in Jerusalem made by this inept and competent immoral leadership results in them having to turn to this new empire that is sprung up way out west there was a rivalry between two potential successors to a global empire the Carthaginians in north Africa and the Romans in central Italy the Romans in the 200s BC quietly way out west defeated the Carthaginians and gradually gained power and influence in the central Mediterranean and then moving into the eastern Mediterranean and by 63 BC the age of the late Roman Republic they had become quite ambitious they were conquering everything Julius Caesar was up north conquering Gaul and Germanic tribes he was all the way into Britain battling against the Celts and Pompeii one of his buddies and political allies had been conquering in the south and now he's the guy who shows up at the request of the Hasmonean dynasty to have Rome come and straighten out all of their political problems and before we talk about what went down when Pompeii showed up when Rome showed up to quote unquote help the later Hasmonean dynasty get things figured out from we'll talk about that tomorrow before we do this seems like as good a place as any to stop and acknowledge a really underappreciated but very important shift that happens in the world between the Old Testament and the New Testament in the Persian era of the Old Testament everything we've been looking at in Ezra and Emaia Esther we're always looking east right we're looking out to modern day Iraq modern day Iran that's where Babylon and Sousa and Persepolis and Prasargiti and the ancient capital of the Medes, Ekbaton all of that stuff is back east that's where the culture happens that's where a lot of the money happened there's a decent amount of money in Asia Minor or Turkey as well Egypt did okay also but the cultural center of gravity the place where everything was happening where it was hopping it was back east during the lateral testament Greece is on the map I mean it's possible that the Philistines you know they had Goliath the giant it's possible that they were Greek-ish in some ways well so Greek culture seafaring Greek influence has been on the map in the Old Testament but it's never really been the focal point it's never been the the place of the center of cultural gravity right but now with what has happened way out west with the Romans fending off their fiercest rival Hannibal and the Carthaginians now all of a sudden they range supreme over the entire western half of the Mediterranean world it's like they got a clean slate to start building with they're not building on top of other well-known ancient empires and everything feels new and alive and exciting with Rome and it's like the poles the cultural poles of the planet shift between the Old Testament and the New Testament with the ascendancy of Rome now everybody starts looking west it was this dinky little frontier town and all of a sudden it's the real thing to look out for all of a sudden it is the place that you appeal for help so the fact that the people in Jerusalem the intellectual spiritual even literal descendants of Elia Shib and Zerubbabel and Ezra Nehemiah the fact that when they got into trouble in the 60s BC that they did not look east to the remnants of old Persia the remnants of old Babylon but instead looked so far west as to be beyond the scope of pretty much anything in the entire Old Testament except maybe Tarsus where Jonah tried to say oh maybe Tarsus was out that way in like Spain or something but pretty much totally off the map of the known biblical world to the west the fact that they're looking out there really should be noted because that is enough to say okay the world of Jesus that we're about to get into my friend so when we get back into the New Testament we're looking at Galatians and stuff it is very different in terms of how people close their eyes and picture the important places in the hot spots from what it was when we left off with Nehemiah anyways we will talk about how things went when Pompeii got the letter to come and help out the Hasmonean dynasty with their problems manyana if you can't tell I'm really enjoying the epilogue and I'm really having fun trying to stitch together the connective tissue here between what we just got done doing and what is coming up next thanks for doing it with me I'm Matt this is the 10 minute Bible hour podcast let's do this again soon you you
